awd_titl_txt: Workshop: Research Needs in Machining and Machine Tools; National Science Foundation; Alexandria, Virginia; March 5-6, 2018
awd_abstract_narration:
This award supports a workshop on machining and machine tool research, to be held at the National Science Foundation (NSF), Alexandria, Virginia, March 5-6, 2018. Machining is a critical approach for the production of high-technology and high value-added products that impact most industries. However, the machine tool industry is under significant international pressure; the hollowing out of machining capability represents a direct threat to national security as well as economic well-being of the United States. The purpose of this workshop is to identify fundamental research needs that will support a resurgence of the US machine tool and expansion of domestic machining capacity. The workshop will bring together key thought leaders from academia, industry, government agencies, trade organizations, and national laboratories for an intensive meeting to identify and prioritize research needs in machining and machine tools.

The workshop will last 1.5 days, and will include thought leaders from industry, government and academe to address the future of machining and machine tools as well as the research accomplishments to date and the basic research needs. Invited speakers will make presentations regarding the future needs for machining capabilities and capacities. Further invited speakers will address funding perspectives, both in terms of needs and the prognosis for funding support. Speakers will be recruited from industry, academe, and government in order to obtain a broad perspective. The objectives of the workshop are to: (1) review the state-of-the-art in basic research in machining; (2) examine future prospects of machine tools and machining; (3) share perspectives on machining from funding agencies such as Department of Defense (DoD), National Institutes of Health (NIH), National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST), and NSF; (4) identify needs, gaps, and challenges facing the machining and machine tools topic areas, for both existing products and new enabled technologies; and (5) formulate recommendations for basic research initiatives.

por.por_cntn:
The objectives of the two-day workshop were to review the state-of-the-art in fundamental research for machining and machine tools; identify priorities, needs, gaps, and challenges facing machine tool builders and users across a broad range of market segments, identify key current and key missing resources for machine tools and machining fundamental research and development; benchmark US machine tools and machining research investments against those from other nations; and formulate recommendations for new initiatives, new policies, and further actions necessary to create a robust US machining and machine tools industry.

The purpose of this workshop was to identify fundamental research and development objects for a resurgent US machine tools and machining industry. The workshop brought together key thought leaders from academia, industry, government agencies, trade organizations, and national laboratories for an intensive 1.5 day meeting to identify and prioritize research needs in machining and machine tools.

The workshop took place at NSF in Alexandria, VA, and included invited speakers and breakout sessions to review the status and research needs in machining and machine tools and to make specific recommendations for fundamental research initiatives, policies, and other actions. Workshop participants included stakeholders from academia, industry, and government. The ideas presented by the speakers and generated from the discussion sessions were summarized in the final report and made available online.

https://mtrc.utk.edu/wp-content/uploads/sites/54/2020/04/final_report_v1.pdf

 An important project outcome was a pilot effort in machine tool base construction that uses additive manufacturing to print a polymer composite mold and concrete to fill the mold while adding mass, stiffness, and damping. This design and testing activity was completed in collaboration with Oak Ridge National Laboratory?s Manufacturing Demonstration Facility. The motivation for this effort is the reduction in the US foundry industry and corresponding requirement for US machine tool builders to purchase cast machine bases from other countries.

Intellectual Merit: The intellectual merit of this workshop included identifying research efforts and funding perspectives that will be needed to close the gap between the future potential and the current state-of-the-art in US machining and machine tools capabilities.

Broader Impacts: Machining and machine tools are used in almost every sector of the economy, so the concerns and outcomes of this workshop have broad, cross-cutting appeal. Machining and machine tools are critical to US manufacturing competitiveness and lead to the creation of many high-technology jobs in fields ranging from defense, to aerospace, transportation, heavy equipment, power generation, optics, and more.  Additionally, the machining and machine tool sector is unique in the large number of small and medium enterprises directly impacted. The ideas coming from the workshop participants are helpful to decision makers in setting coordinated priorities and strategies for fundamental research in machining and machine tools at government agencies, academic institutions, and industrial companies.
